results.title: Angel on my shoulder
results.creator_credit: Archie Mayo and Charles R. Rogers
results.brief_description: Film Noir classic wherein the devil promises leniency to a dead gangster if he will return to earth and take over the body of a judge who is stamping out evil. Stars Claude Rains, Paul Muni and Anne Baxter.
results.description: Film Noir classic wherein the devil promises leniency to a dead gangster if he will return to earth and take over the body of a judge who is stamping out evil. Stars Claude Rains, Paul Muni and Anne Baxter.

results.title: Angel of vengeance = Ms.45
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Navaron Films and Rochelle Films
results.brief_description: Abel Ferrara’s (‘Bad Lieutenant’, ‘King of New York’, ‘Driller Killer’) foray into the revenge fantasy genre is an often unnerving film which owes a lot to Roman Polanski’s disturbing tale of sexual terror, ‘Repulsion’. Set in the rough garment district of New York, ‘Angel of Vengeance’ follows the gradual descent into madness of Thana (Zoe Tamerlis), a mute seamstress who snaps after she is raped twice in one day. Her reaction to it plays like a strange form of liberation, as the once timid seamstress proceeds to off some of the more sleazier male citizens of New York city. Ferrara sprinkles this unusual and stylish low budget film with dark comic moments, eccentric characters (like Thana’s weird landlady played by Editta Sherman), and its slow motion climax is a beautiful and surreal piece of filmmaking. Cast includes Albert Sinkys, Darlene Stuto, Helen McGara, Nike Zachmanoglou.

results.title: Angel in the house
results.creator_credit: Jane Jackson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: The film takes as its theme an essay by Virginia Woolf written in 1927. In the essay Virginia Woolf talks about women writers and the psychological and social barriers to their creativity and their self-confidence. In 1977, the film’s protagonist Lily Ramsey is an aspiring writer, and an admirer of Virginia Woolf. In an attempt to complete her first novel, she takes a break from her job in London and goes home to the small seaside town where her family still lives. However, for Lily home is not simply a peaceful place to write, but part of the experience which she brings to bear on her writing.

results.title: Angel food
results.creator_credit: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Animated film that charts the short-lived adventures of an intrepid strawberry as it evades a variety of kitchen hazards - including vicious utensils, distraction by a Busby Berkeley-style fruit mambo, and a seductive but ultimately deadly pot of melted chocolate - to fulfill its quest to sit atop a decadent whipped cream and meringue dessert. “A glossy tale with a sticky end.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts

results.title: Angel exit. Sekala has to die
results.creator_credit: Vladimir Michalek, Jaroslav Boucek and BUC Film
results.brief_description: Two very different films from Czechoslovakian filmmaker Vladimir Michalek. “Angel exit” is a gritty urban drama set in a lower class milieu, an outer suburb of Prague. Mikes is a young man with a criminal record and a history of drug abuse whose girlfriend implores him to change so they may make a life together. Lukas, Mikes best friend and Kaja, another young addict, encourage Lukas to continue using. The three of them are unable to forge an existence beyond the realms of petty crime, perpetual scoring and getting high. Filmed on digital, “Angel exit” utilises the style of cinema verite, and has a pallid colour scheme that reflects the futility of its angry and abusive protagonists. “Sekala has to die” is a World War II period drama, set in a rural Czech village where two interlopers - Sekala and Zaprdek, threaten the local community. Sekala is the half brother of Oberva, a highly regarded member of the town, who is respected by their father. When Sekala’s demands press the tolerance of the locals a young blacksmith is chosen to execute Sekala and rid them of his menace. Beautifully photographed, “Sekala has to die” is a moral tale, seeped in the typical golden tones of European art house cinema.

results.title: Angel baby
results.creator_credit: Michael Rymer, Timothy White, Jonathan Shteinman, Stamen and Meridian Films
results.brief_description: A funny, haunting love story, this film tells the story of two lost souls, Harry and Kate who fall in love against the odds and find the hope and strength in each other to accomplish the impossible. Jacqueline McKenzie and John Lynch star as two people with psychological problems who must also overcome many obstacles on the path to happiness, not the least of which is the pre-conceived notions of other people. Full of humour, compassion and hope this is a testament to the power of love; a roller coaster journey to the magical fringes of the human psyche.

results.title: Angel at my table: a trilogy [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jane Campion, Bridget Ikin and Hibiscus Films
results.brief_description: This trilogy re-creates the life of New Zealand’s prize winning author Janet Frame, based on her visions of herself and her times. The first part, ‘To the Is-Land’, deals with Janet’s childhood in Oamaru in the 1930’s. Part two, ‘An Angel at my Table’, is an account of her disturbing experiences after being committed to an institution. In the final part, ‘The Envoy from Mirror City’, after an uneasy fellowship with Europe’s artistic-set, Janet returns to New Zealand conveying a sense of confidence and hope. Adapted by Laura Jones from the three volumes of Frame’s autobiography. Starring Kerry Fox, Alexia Keogh and Karen Fergusson. Cinematography by Stuart Dryburgh.

results.title: Angel
results.creator_credit: Derek May, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: High contrast film stock is used to give a silhouette effect. Music is by Leonard Cohen. This is a film about a young man, a girl and a dog in which the visuals are over exposed. The girl tries to fly with wings which are more symbolic than practical and the dog and young man make similar attempts. This film won awards at Columbus, Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver.

results.title: Angel
results.creator_credit: Dennis K. Smith, Open Channel Productions and Sharyn Prentice
results.brief_description: You may not know the name Deborah Halpern, but you will certainly recognise her ceramic sculpture with its unique tiling located out the front of the National Gallery of Victoria. Hers is the story of a young ceramic sculptor with no formal training whose public profile has proliferated as the result of an unexpected major commission from one of Australia’s most prestigious art galleries. Deborah Haplpern’s art is inspired by Niki de Phalle, the ‘Art Brut’ movement and the ‘Outsider’ artists of Europe who live and work outside the mainstream gallery system. In this documentary Deborah talks intimately about the influence of these artists on her work and life. It outlines the structure of her sculpture, Angel, as well as the artistic and intellectual processes and motivation behind her work. This is a story of achievement. It is a passionate account of a two year project, the journey of a young artist and her triumphant arrival into the public art forum.

results.title: Andy Warhol: the complete picture
results.creator_credit: Chris Radley, Randy Barbato, Fenton Bailey, Channel Four and Bravo Network
results.brief_description: Fascinating documentary about the life and work of one of the twentieth century’s most influential artists - Andy Warhol. Originally born Andrew Warhola to immigrant Slovakian parents, this tale starts with a history of his family life in Pittsburgh and travails his life’s work up to his death in 1987. Not unlike his films, the vision lingers on the exteriors of buildings, the beauty of the everyday through signs and architecture set against a moving sky. The facts are rendered easily to memory as the images are beautiful to watch and the narration by Julian Rhind-Tutt engaging. The only American artist to have a museum dedicated to him, Warhol’s obsessive behaviour in documenting his life (over 600 time capsules were created by the artist) fills the museum. His audio-tapes, art, magazine publishing, band and other enterprises are discussed through interviews with friends, family and fans and demonstrated by an elegant assemblage of photos and ephemera.
